ac9cc1fe228e.title: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind.

paragraphs.text: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind. An engineer who makes a decision based on internal processes that just happens to affect the customer experience is not designing anything.

paragraphs.text: I would agree that everyone can affect the product experience but I always think of designing as an intentional act. So I wouldn’t say they’re designing the product until they have an intent behind their actions.

ccc04c2e6668.title: This is the TL;DR of the TWO articles written about this idea.

paragraphs.text: This is the TL;DR of the TWO articles written about this idea. Apply this idea to where you fit into an organization — it isn’t a unique trait to Designers. It doesn’t make you a designer, but it will make you really successful at what you do. A user-centered Marketer, a user-center Engineer, a user-center Product Manager, etc.

The resistance is also from those those without the title of “designer”, that believe that their world is locked into and defined by their own title. Like that CEO, they don’t yet even realize that design is not just the room down the hall.

96546bb60bc.bio: I nudge pixels at 3200% in NYC.
96546bb60bc.name: Ben Gold

paragraphs.text: Having more people who do design is additive, not competitive. These designers make your team and your product stronger, because they’re contributing from their unique perspectives. Help them bolster their skills, and use their expertise to the advantage of your product and company.
paragraphs.name: c872

paragraphs.text: Whether you like it or not, whether you approve it or not, people outside of your design team are making significant design choices that affect your customers in important ways. They are designing your product. They are designers.
paragraphs.name: 33c1

paragraphs.text: This shouldn’t be provocative — it’s just a statement of fact. I work with dozens of startups every year, and I see it happen at every one. A CFO makes a pricing decision and changes the product experience. An engineer makes a performance trade-off. A salesperson calls on a customer. In my view, people who fundamentally change the customer’s experience are designers.
paragraphs.name: ed87

paragraphs.text: Does everyone need all the skills of a designer? Of course not. But each person needs to be armed with the tools to understand how their decisions affect the customer experience.

Focusing on the core business is what differentiates real product design from interface design or even user experience design. Fundamental product design is really hard and requires a lot of legwork, but this is what designers at the highest level do — and it’s why their work is better than yours.
paragraphs.name: f2f3

paragraphs.text: Maybe that’s why so many designers are offended when non-designers do design work or get called “designers” by Jared and me. You can act offended if you want, but the reality is that other people are making design decisions with or without you. Embrace them . They don’t make your job less valuable. They don’t make your job title less meaningful.
paragraphs.name: f37f
